personalInfo.splInterest: Video games, hanging out with friends, Legos

tourBios.otherCarHigh: Was a four-time all-state golfer in high school, playing on two state championship teams...Was runner-up at the Provo Open and third at the Utah Open (and low amateur)...Competed at the 2009 AJGA Canon Cup, helping his team to a win...Won four individual titles while at BYU...Was a third-team All-American his junior season (2011-12) and named to that year's Ben Hogan Award Watch List...Finished eagle-birdie-birdie-par-eagle to qualifying for his first U.S. Amateur...Played in his first Web.com Tour event, at the 2013 Utah Championship (missed the cut)...Qualified for the Web.com Tour Qualifying School Finals by finishing T7 at the second-stage qualifier at Bear Creek GC in Murrieta, Calif.
tourBios.personal: Attended Fremont High School in Plain City, Utah...Father, James, played for BYU from 1974-77 and was teammates with future TOUR players Mike Brannan, John Fought, Pat McGowan, Jim Nelford and Mike Reid. He also made 22 PGA TOUR starts between 1981 and 2002, including 13 in 1984...Earliest golf memory was caddying for his dad...Biggest thrill outside golf is powder skiing in Park City, Utah...Favorite course played is Oakmont CC...Favorite teams are BYU and the New England Patriots...Favorite athlete is Tom Brady, who he'd like to trade places with for a day "to play an NFL game."....Favorite TV shows are "Dexter" and "Homeland," favorite books are from the "Harry Potter" series and favorite movies are "Forrest Gump" and "Remember the Titans"...Favorite entertainer is Eminem...Favorite vacation spot is North Shore of Hawaii...Dream foursome would include his dad, Tiger Woods and Brady...Not many people know he collects Legos...Motto is "Big-time players make big-time putts."...Entrance song to first tee would be "My First Song" by Jay-Z...Twitter name is "@z_blair.

tourBios.carHigh: 2015: After two missed cuts and a T43 in his first three starts of the 2015-16 PGA TOUR Season, finished T10 at the OHL Classic at Mayakoba in his second appearance in Mexico...Entered the final round of the Sony Open in Hawaii tied with Brandt Snedeker for the 54-hole lead (the first such lead/co-lead of his career), then fired a final-round 3-under 67 to finish solo third and was just one shot out of a playoff for a chance to win his first career PGA TOUR event. Was attempting to become just the 10th player to make the Sony Open in Hawaii his first PGA TOUR win. Two of his four career top-10 finishes have occured at the Sony Open in Hawaii (including a T6 in 2015), with his third-place effort in 2016 topping his previous-best TOUR finish of T4 at The Barclays in 2015. Week included a 52-hole bogey-free streak that came to an end at the par-3 fourth hole Sunday.

tourBios.carHigh:
2014-15: On the strength of seven top-25 finishes in 31 starts through the Wyndham Championship, became one of nine rookies to advance to the FedExCup Playoffs. A top-five finish in the first event, The Barclays, ensured starts at the Deutsche Bank Championship and BMW Championship. Became one of just four rookies to make it to Conway Farms GC outside Chicago, with only Daniel Berger advancing to the TOUR Championship by Coca-Cola...Recorded the first top-10 finish of his PGA TOUR career with a T6 showing at the Sony Open in Hawaii. With rounds of 71-66-64-67, finished 12-under 268, 11 strokes behind runaway winner Jimmy Walker...Thanks to four rounds in the 60s, including a final-round 4-under 66, finished T4 at The Barclays, nine strokes behind champion Jason Day. His play at Plainfield CC punched his ticket with five other rookies to the Deutsche Bank Championship. Jumped from No. 106 to No. 45 in the FedExCup standings, one of eight players to play their way into the second Playoffs' event.

2013-14: Despite starting the season with limited conditional status, ended up making 12 Web.com Tour starts, which led to two runner-up performances, six top-25s and eight cuts made...Began the year playing LatinoamĂŠrica. Entered seven events from March through May, making every cut but one...Earned his first top-10 at the 83 Abierto OSDE del Centro in April when he finished T6...Missed his only cut the next week, then picked up his second top-10 three weeks later, at the Domincan Republic Open. Rounds of 66-71-74-69 led to a T5...The very next week, at the Lexus Panama Classic, was in contention but a final-round 73 derailed any hopes of victory, and he settled for a T6...From Panama he headed to Canada for his lone PGA TOUR Canada appearance of 2014, a missed cut at the PC Financial Open in Vancouver...In early June, shot rounds of 69-68 at Emerald Valley GC in Creswell, Ore., to earn medalist honors at U.S. Open sectional qualifying. Defeated Clayton Rask by four shots to qualify for his first U.S. Open, a championship his father, Jimmy, played in in 1981 (missed the cut). Finished T40, with his dad coming under the ropes and carrying his golf bag from his approach shot onto the green on the 72nd hole at Pinehurst No. 2...Returned to Canada in early July for his first of 12 Web.com Tour appearances. Carded 70-67 over final 36 holes of the Nova Scotia Open to move from T31 when the day began to a T7, collecting his first Web.com Tour top-10 in the process. Was already in the next week's Utah Championship via a sponsor's exemption, but the T7 allowed him entry into the tournament on his own...At his hometown event outside Salt Lake City, shot four under-par rounds at Willow Creek CC to T11 and earn another invite, this one into the next week's Albertsons Boise Open...Made the cut in Boise and his next two tournaments...Contended for his first title in his sixth Tour start, at the Price Cutter Charity Championship. A final-round 66 resulted in a T2 finish, one behind Cameron Percy's 21-under-par winning effort. He improved to 41st on the money list...He would close the Regular Season with a T14 at the WinCo Foods Portland Open to get to 38th in earnings and comfortably qualify for the Web.com Tour Finals...Missed the cut in the first three Finals events...His real coming out was at the season-ending Web.com Tour Championship, where he opened with a then course record-tying 63. He would go on to either lead or be in second place after all four rounds, with his finish a solo second, following a Sunday 68 that left him one shy of winner Derek Fathauer. His perserverance and performance under the pressure created many admirers. He went from $0 earned in the Finals to 11th in the TOUR's priority ranking with his special and timely week...Was fourth on Tour in Scoring Average (69.20).

dyn.dynResults: His best finish on the PGA TOUR in 2016 is 3rd at the Sony Open in Hawaii.
dyn.dynStats: He ranks T93rd in Approach 100-125 yards (RTP Sc on the PGA TOUR.
